JUST IN: Chairs @RepPeterDeFazio and @GraceNapolitano condemn the Trump administration for weakening the environmental review process that has protected public health and ensured public participation since 1970. Read more here: https://transportation.house.gov/news/press-releases/chairs-defazio-napolitano-condemn-trump-administration-for-weakening-environmental-review-process-that-has-protected-public-health-and-ensured-public-participation-since-1970

NEPA led to decades of environmental progress that went hand in hand with public participation in project planning and the federal decision-making process.

The Trump Administration is trying to roll back that progress.

NEPA requires federal agencies to engage the public and consider the real environmental costs and potential consequences of all types of projects.

For many communities, NEPA has been a bulwark against projects that could harm the environment, human health or quality of life.

"Pollution had gotten bad enough to be undeniable...In 1963, smog had killed 400 New Yorkers, and Lake Erie‚Äôs oxygen content had become so depleted that the center of the lake sustained precious little life." https://time.com/4696104/environmental-protection-agency-1970-history/
Before NEPA was signed into law, industries polluted our waterways with impunity and factories spewed toxic fumes into the air, cloaking our communities in thick smog.

Before NEPA was signed into law, garbage littered our shores and rivers were so polluted with waste they would spontaneously catch on fire. https://www.michiganradio.org/post/50-years-ago-today-rouge-river-caught-fire

"Millions of Americans watched in horror as shocking images of oil-drenched sea birds, elephant seals, dolphins and other animals, some clinging to life and others already dead, played out during extensive news coverage [on TV sets] across the country." https://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/50-years-after-the-santa-barbara-oil-spill-how-the-catastrophe-sparked-a-modern-environmental-movement/337524

Before NEPA was signed into law, Americans had witnessed the devastating toll after millions of gallons of oil spilled off the California coast at Santa Barbara, killing thousands of birds and other marine wildlife.

50 years ago, President Richard Nixon signed the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) into law in response to widespread public concern over the worsening conditions of our nation‚Äôs environment.

As the United States waged a war abroad, environmental crises mounted at home.

The READI Act will ensure that we can count on receiving these alerts during wildfires and other emergencies. I‚Äôm proud that my bill is one of 30 bipartisan bills that we passed out of @EnergyCommerce during today‚Äôs markup.

As we continue to battle #COVID19, this year‚Äôs wildfire season presents unprecedented challenges for first responders and the public, especially when it comes to evacuations. This makes it even more crucial that we have emergency alerting systems that are robust and reliable.

Because of the #climatecrisis, the wildfire season in California and across the West is starting earlier and ending later each year. Our state is already in the midst of another dry, hot summer and bracing for a likely dire wildfire season.

Today, @EnergyCommerce voted to approve my bill, H.R. 6096, the READI Act. This legislation will improve the reliability of emergency alerts ‚Äî lifesaving tools to disseminate information to the public during times of emergency.
